title: Nando's customers blast restaurant over 'racist' picture hung next to toilets
text:

A new Nando's restaurant has come under fire over a piece of artwork that has been branded 'racist' by customers.

Visitors to the eatery in Birmingham were stunned when they spotted the picture hanging next to the men's toilets yesterday.

The painting, created for the restaurant by South African artist Khaya Sineyile, shows four black people in a toaster.

However, the popular restaurant chain has since removed it and apologised after receiving several complaints, reports Birmingham Live.

The drama erupted the day after the branch opened at One Stop Shopping Centre in Perry Barr.

Customer Wayne Yafai said he was offended by the painting when he visited on the opening day.

(Image: Birmingham Live WS)

The 33-year-old, from Handsworth, said: "I had just been to the men's toilet, came out and saw this painting facing me. I found it so offensive. I am mixed race, half Arabic and half English.

"I took a picture of the painting and showed it to my black friends. They were really offended by it and felt it was racist and couldn't see why Nando's would use such a painting in one of its restaurants."

He added: "We sent a complaint to Nando's and they did respond to us to apologise and to try offer an explanation. But we still don't know what the hidden message is behind the artwork."

(Image: Birmingham Live WS)

A Nando’s spokesman said it had removed the painting following the complaints and apologised for any misinterpretation.

He said: "As a proudly South African brand we are the biggest collectors of Southern African art in the world and every Nando’s restaurant displays original artworks from artists based in our homeland.

"Often these works depict scenes from South Africa’s history or comment on the current social situations there.

(Image: Birmingham Live WS)

"In this instance artist, Khaya Sineyile, from the New Crossroads township in Nyanga, Cape Town, takes issue with the far-reaching effects of social inequality in South Africa.

"Using common household objects in juxtaposition with his subjects Khaya aims to create discussion around issues often ignored.

"We understand art is subjective and without context the work could be misinterpreted, we have apologised for any offence this artwork might have caused."
description: The popular fast food chain has since removed the artwork from its Birmingham branch and apologised after visitors including Wayne Yafai, 33, branded it "offensive"
